DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said we are looking to be ahead of schedule to sign Phase 1 US/China deal. (Newswires)

USTR office is to consider starting November 1st, extensions of certain tariff exclusions on USD 34bln of Chinese goods, while it added the exclusions on certain tariffs are set to expire on December 28th and an extension would be for a year. (Newswires)

US FCC will vote in November to prohibit companies from using government programme funds to purchase equipment from companies deemed as a national security risk, while reports added the FCC will designate Huawei and ZTE as such companies leaving the companies 30 days to contest. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said in a letter to EU Council President that the UK has accepted the EU's extension offer (as mandated by the Benn Act) and expressed that it is against his wishes. This was after European Council President Tusk announced that the EU27 has agreed that it will accept the UK's request for a Brexit "flextension" until 31 January 2020 with the decision expected to be formalised through a written procedure. (Newswires)

UK lawmakers rejected PM Johnson's request for an early election with 299 MP's voting in favour, short of the 2/3rds (434) majority needed. Following the defeat, UK PM Johnson said we will not allow this paralysis to continue and will give notice of a short bill for an election on December 12th, while the government confirmed it will not try again to bring the WAB back and noted it does not agree on the Liberal Democrats date on the 9th as they are not sure they can get the bill through in time. (Newswires/BBC)

UK Government source earlier noted UK PM Johnson will table a one-line bill for a vote on Tuesday on a general election on within the range of December 9th-12th and other reports stated it is likely to be a similar bill to Liberal Democrats and SNP which amends the Fixed-term Parliaments Act and fixes an election for December 9th. (The Sun/Newswires/Twitter)

UK opposition Labour party had instructed lawmakers to abstain in early election vote, internal party document confirms. It was separately reported that the consensus from Shadow Cabinet is that they’re certain there will be an election so it’s a matter of how we get there and on what terms according to an attendee, while the decision was not to vote for tonight’s FTPA motion and instead wait and see what tomorrow’s one line bill looks like. Furthermore, a majority of the Shadow Cabinet want the party to make it clear we should get on with the WAB and the election is not in the national interest, according to The Sun's Deputy Political Editor. (Newswires/The Sun/Twitter)

UK Downing Street is reportedly in talks with Labour Leavers and ex-Tories about bringing another programme motion for the Withdrawal Bill tomorrow, according to Daily Mail's Grove. (Daily Mail/Twitter)

ECB's Outgoing President Draghi said monetary policy can still achieve its objective, but this can be achieved faster and with less side effects if fiscal policies are aligned. Draghi also suggested that more active Euro Area fiscal policy would allow for faster policy adjustments and higher rates but reiterated the ECB will use all the tools within its mandate to reach its goal. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Energy Minister and Nigeria's Energy Minister discuss oil markets and joint cooperation between the OPEC+ members to maintain market stability. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Israeli PM Netanyahu said Iran has begun deploying missiles inside Yemen in order to strike targets in Israel. (ELINT News)

 

US

US House Speaker Pelosi announced in a letter to Democrats that the House will vote to formalize the procedures related to impeachment inquiry of President Trump. (FT)

  • US Advanced Goods Trade Balance (Sep) -70.39B (Prev. -73.06B)
  • US Retail Inventories Ex-Auto (Sep) 0.3% (Prev. -0.2%)
  • US Wholesale Inventories (Sep) -0.3% (Prev. 0.2%)

 

MARKET RECAP

The positive rhetoric on US-China trade continued as China’s MOFCOM stated the technical consultations of some of the text agreement for the deal with US were basically completed and that the sides agreed to properly handle their core concerns; China’s Global Times noted that this is the first time the Chinese side signalled that a partial agreement may be within reach. Further signs of positivity were seen from US President Trump who announced they are looking to be ahead of schedule when signing the Phase 1 deal with China. The comments from Trump spurred a risk on appetite across markets as stocks printed all-time highs and outflows of safe havens, with XAU falling beneath the 1500 level and USDJPY rising to fresh session highs. Moves in havens and equities caught further wind at the cash open. Microsoft (MSFT) emerged the victor in the USD 10bln JEDI cloud contract from the Pentagon, seeing the tech titan elevate indices, whilst competitor Amazon (AMZN) took a hit on the surprise loss. Tiffany (TIF) spiked, reaching gains of up to 30%, after France-based LVMH (MC FP) approached it with a USD 14.5bln takeover offer; TIF said it was considering the deal, but it is expected to reject this initial bid. PG&E (PCG) tumbled amid it cutting power of close to 3mln customers as weather conditions deteriorate in the Sunshine State, local competitor Edison International (EIX) also traded lower. Prologis (PLD) traded in the red after making an all-stock acquisition offer for competitor REIT, Liberty Property Trust (LPT), which spiked higher on the USD 12.5bln EV bid. S&P 500 0.6% at 3039, NASDAQ-100 1% at 8111, Dow Jones 0.5% at 27091.

The pick-up in risk appetite saw rates continue to backup to start the week. The TPLEX trundled lower throughout the European session and remained at lows in the US session whilst participants pushed US equity bourses to new ATHs. The US Treasury announced it expects to issue USD 352bln (Prior estimate 381bln) in net marketable debt in Q4 19, and USD 389bln in Q1 20, saying it borrowed USD 440bln in Q3 19. By settlement the curve had mainly bear steepened, with both 2s10s and 2s30s 2.5bps wider, with the 2-year yield up by 2bps. US T-note (z9) settled 12 ticks lower at 129-05.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - US MARKET WRAP 28th October 2019: Stocks print all-time highs on extended trade optimism
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities higher, Treasuries lower, crude lower, dollar flat
  • REAR VIEW: Trump expects to sign phase one deal sooner than expected, UK government lose request for early general election, China Industrial profits fall, US advanced goods trade balance deficit narrows slightly, LVMH make offer for TIF, T firmer on earnings
  • COMING-UP: Data: US Consumer Confidence & Pending Home Sales. Speakers: BoE's Carney. Supply: UK I/L. Earnings: Pfizer, Amgen, AMD, Mastercard, BP, Fresenius SE, Fresenius Medical

* CHINA: The positive rhetoric on US China trade continued from Friday as China’s MOFCOM stated the technical consultations of some of the text agreement for the deal with US were basically completed and that the sides agreed to properly handle their core concerns; China’s Global Times noted that this is the first time the Chinese side signalled that a partial agreement may be within reach. Further signs of positivity were seen from US President Trump who announced they are looking to be ahead of schedule when signing the Phase 1 deal with China. The comments from Trump spurred a risk on appetite across markets as stocks printed all-time highs and outflows of safe havens, with XAU falling beneath the 1500 level and USDJPY rising to fresh session highs. Moves in havens and equities caught further wind at the cash open.

* BREXIT: UK lawmakers rejected UK PM Johnson’s request for an early election as only 299 MP’s voted in favour, short of the 2/3rds majority, which required 434 MPS. UK PM Johnson will now issue a bill tomorrow for a 12th of December election, which would only require a simple majority. Liberal Democrat source suggested that they may back the Government’s one-line bill for a general election, but the bill would have to meet three conditions of avoiding no deal Brexit, dropping the WAB and the date must be “set in stone”. The UK Government later confirmed they will not try again to bring the WAB back, although they do not agree with the Lib Dems date (Dec. 9th) as they do not believe it provides enough time to get the bill through, according to BBC. 

* US ADVANCED GOODS TRADE BALANCE: The deficit narrowed to USD 70.4bln from USD 72.8bln; the consensus was expecting a deficit of USD 73.5bln. September's deficit was the smallest since June 2018, but Pantheon Macroeconomics does not believe that it will last. "The 1.6% drop in exports was worse then we expected, and it completes the second straight quarterly decline, but it was more than offset by an unexpected 2.3% plunge in imports," the consultancy notes, "a 5.0% drop in imports of consumer goods accounts for nearly three-fifths of this decline, following a 3.5% jump in August." Pantheon says it assumes these swings were in response to the imposition of tariffs on many imported Chinese consumer goods on 1st September 1, but suggests that imports will likely mean-revert in October, though it expects that export weakness will persist, judging by the export sub-component in the latest ISM data. In wake of the data, the Atlanta Fed's GDPnow tracker was revised down by one-tenth to 1.7%.

* CHINESE INDUSTRIAL PROFITS: fell by 5.3% in September, the steepest drop since 2015 and a ramped-up pace of decline from the prior 2.0% decline. The Chinese bureau attributed the fall due to the decline in industrial product prices and slower sales growth. Analysts note that although production figures in China picked up in September, the deflationary pressures continue to weigh on corporate profits and their debt profiles.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.6% at 3039, NASDAQ-100 1% at 8111, Dow Jones 0.5% at 27091

* S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.4%, Consumer Staples -0.2%, Energy -0.6%, Financials 0.5%, Health Care 1%, Industrials 0.3%, Information Technology 1.3%, Materials 0.3%, Telecommunication Services 1.2%, Utilities -1.3%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Microsoft (MSFT) emerged victor in the USD 10bln JEDI cloud contract from the Pentagon, seeing the tech titan elevate indices, whilst competitor Amazon (AMZN) took a hit on the surprise loss. Tiffany (TIF) spiked, reaching gains of up to 30%, after France-based LVMH (MC FP) approached it with a USD 14.5bln takeover offer; TIF said it was considering the deal, but it is expected to reject this initial bid. PG&E (PCG) tumbled amid it cutting power of close to 3mln customers as weather conditions deteriorate in the Sunshine State, local competitor Edison International (EIX) also traded lower. Prologis (PLD) traded in the red after making an all-stock acquisition offer for competitor REIT, Liberty Property Trust (LPT), which spiked higher on the USD 12.5bln EV bid.

* EARNINGS: AT&T (T) reported an inline Q3 earnings report but opened higher on the disclosure of its three-year capital allocation plan, to which activist investor Elliott Management gave its seal of approval to. Walgreens (WBA) held in the green on beating top and bottom line estimates and raising its annual cost savings target, although EPS guidance was slightly soft. Spotify (SPOT) bounced higher on a stellar earnings report, recording a surprise EPS and strong MAUs. DTE Energy (DTE) was subdued after an EPS miss. Restaurant Brands (QSR) took a hit after missing top and bottom line estimates, despite the announcement of the prodigal Popeyes Chicken Burger. ON Semiconductor (ON) surged on meeting expectations for earnings and guidance, providing some relief to the semiconductor sector.

* BROKER MOVES: Roku (ROKU) made strong gains after being initiated with a Buy rating at BofAML. Ventas (VTR) took a hit with gratitude to downgrades at both Capital One and Citi. Stocks benefitting from upgrades included Atlassian (TEAM) at BofAML, First Solar (FSLR) at JMP, JetBlue Airways (JBLU) at JPMorgan. Conversely, stocks hit on downgrades included Alaska Air (ALK) at JPMorgan, American Eagle (AEO) at Citi, Cabot (COG) at Susquehanna (note energy was also hit from lower crude prices), Estee Lauder (EL) at Piper Jaffray, Lululemon (LULU) at Citi, PVH (PVH) at JPMorgan.

* GEOPOLITICS: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin announced that the US will ramp up more sanctions on Iran, adding the current sanctions are working and cutting off money for Iran. Elsewhere, ELINT news reported comments from Israel’s PM Netanyahu, who said Iran was setting up missiles in Yemen to target Israel. As such, Israel reportedly set up precautionary measures by increasing its readiness and adjusted its air defences as it prepares for a potential Iranian cruise missile or suicide drone attack as there is concern over recent Iranian activity. Over the weekend, president Trump something big has just happened, which was later to be revealed as the death of IS leader Baghdadi, as a US team raised a location in Syria. The death has spurred some worry of potential retaliatory attacks, and as such, France’s Interior Minister instructed police to be on high alert to prevent the potential attacks.

* WTI (Z9) SETTLES USD 0.85 LOWER AT USD 55.81/BBL; BRENT (Z9) SETTLES USD 0.45 LOWER AT USD 61.57/BBL: Crude benchmarks failed to find impetus from the rise in equity bourses, moving lower through the session, paring gains from last week as a dent in Chinese industrial profits hit investor sentiment. Book squaring as a function of the expiry of Brent Dec’19 options on Monday is also of note. Looking ahead to the US energy inventories, crude stocks are seen building 0.7mln bbls, whilst distillates and gasoline are both seen drawing 2.3mln bbls.

* US T-NOTE (Z9) SETTLED 12 TICKS LOWER AT 129-05.

The pick-up in risk appetite saw rates continue to backup to start the week. The TPLEX trundled lower throughout the European session and remained at lows in the US session whilst participants pushed US equity bourses to new ATHs. The US Treasury announced it expects to issue USD 352bln (Prior estimate 381bln) in net marketable debt in Q4 19, and USD 389bln in Q1 20, saying it borrowed USD 440bln in Q3 19. By settlement the curve had mainly bear steepened, with both 2s10s and 2s30s 2.5bps wider, with the 2-year yield up by 2bps.

* FX WRAP:DXY was relatively flat today although the buck was trending lower in early trade but reversed throughout the remainder of the session as President Trump announced they are appearing ahead of schedule to sign the phase 1 trade deal, which saw outflows of havens and thus provided slight strength to the DXY. GBP was firmer to start the week as the EU granted an extension request to 31st October, which was later confirmed by UK PM Johnson and the EU, further diminishing the chance of a no deal Brexit. Also adding to the mix, Cable saw minor upside once UK lawmakers rejected UK PM Johnson’s request for an early election, however this was very much expected. Haven’s took a clear direction today due to the continuation of positive US/China trade rhetoric which saw USDJPY trade to highs of 109.03, finding resistance at the 200dma at 109.05; the x resides just beneath the 109-handle heading into ASIAPAC trade. CHF also traded lower to start the week, albeit relatively flat against the Dollar, but weaker against EUR and GBP. XAU trades beneath the USD 1500/oz level heading into overnight trade falling from highs at 1508 to lows of 1490. EMFX varied to start the week, ZAR traded firmer as is Eskom announced that no load shedding is expected to occur today and there is a low probability of any load shedding this week. ARS and TRY outperformed against the greenback with the former benefiting from central bank intervention despite Fernandez’s election win; TRY performing well amid a continued silence on the Syria front.

* ARGENTINA ELECTIONS: Populist opposition leader Fernandez beat the market-friendly Macri (whose policies had some success in controlling inflation and turning the economy onto a sustainable path) by 48% vs 40%, avoiding the need for a run-off next month. The outcome lead the Argentine central bank to tighten currency controls in order to preserve Argentina's USD 43.5bln of FX reserves, and has limited Argentines' ability to purchase US dollars to USD 200 per month (from USD 10k per month), through 10th December. Pantheon Macroeconomics said the election opens the door to severe uncertainty under a new Peronist government. "Mr. Fernández and his vice-president, former president Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, has the potential to mark the start of a renewed chapter of economic and financial chaos. We believe that the new president will seek to implement populist policies, due to his Peronist credentials and closeness to the Kirchners, so markets should brace for more volatility," and notes that the previous 12-year Kirchnerist era was characterised by wild inflation, huge public deficits and unsustainable subsidies.

Daily FX Wrap: risk appetite stirred by Brexit/UK politics and stoked by Trump
content:
GBP/JPY/CHF

Sterling was already underpinned on the 1.2800 handle against the Dollar and above 0.8650 vs the Euro before early buy orders triggered a few stops before confirmation that the EU has granted the UK a further Article 50 extension to January 31st via EC President Tusk. However, the Pound derived more traction amidst growing GE momentum and hardly stumbled when headlines broke indicating that main opposition party Labour intends to abstain from tonight’s vote on PM Johnson’s motion to go to the polls on December 12 as the Government held meetings with the Lib Dems and SNP to discuss alternative GE dates with conditions, and even the possibility of a new longer Programme Motion. Indeed, Cable extended gains to circa 1.2876 and just above the 10 DMA (1.2873), while Eur/Gbp finally breached its 21 DMA (0.8629) to open up 0.8600 again. Conversely, the Yen and Franc both extended ranges to the downside in wake of more bullish comments from US President Trump on the state of Chinese trade talks just after he pronounced that Wall Street is heading for a good day. Usd/Jpy matched the previous 108.94 October peak, but faded ahead of the psychological 109.00 level and the 200 DMA (109.06), while Usd/Chf reached 0.9970 and Eur/Chf around 1.1059 before waning.

AUD/NZD

The Antipodean Dollars were on divergent paths for the most part, as the Aussie consolidated above the 0.6800 handle and Aud/Nzd hurdled 1.0750 in contrast to Nzd/Usd that retreated through 0.6350. The Kiwi may have lacked support from NZ participants due to the local Labour Day holiday, while comments from RBA’s Lowe on Tuesday and/or CPI data on Wednesday could provide the Aussie with more impetus.

EUR/CAD

A bit more gyrating around the 1.1100 and 1.3050 marks vs their US counterpart as the Euro failed to sustain gains on its big figure break and was already back under before the NY cut when a hefty option expiry ran off (1.3 bn). Comments from departing ECB President Draghi did not really impact the single currency and softer than forecast Eurozone M3 data was largely overlooked, but higher Eurozone yields did provide some early traction alongside the aforementioned positive Brextension. Meanwhile, the Loonie had a good look at Fib support (1.3151), but failed to penetrate the technical level or 1.3050 ahead of the BoC on Wednesday and just hours in front of the Fed, as the DXY regrouped within a 97.670-896 range band and broadly shrugged off mixed US data in advance of more high profile releases later in the week, like NFP.

EM

The general upturn in risk sentiment noted above exacerbated Try and Zar rallies to 5.7150+ and almost 14.5250 vs the Usd respectively, with the Lira still benefiting from relative calm on the Turkish-Syrian front and less angst from the US and other international nations in response, while the Rand was boosted that Eskom is back to full power ahead of this week’s SA budget and Moody’s ratings review. However, the Argentine Peso only managed to stop the rot in wake of Fernandez’ election victory with the aid of official intervention in the form of capital controls, in stark contrast to Brazil’s Real that continued to revel in pension reform relief if not glory and appeared to take in stride consensus expectations for a 50 bp BCB ease on Wednesday.

subject: BREXIT UPDATE: Momentum gathering behind single line election bill, tonight's FTPA motion still likely to fail
content:
* THE LATEST: If the UK Government’s FTPA motion fails tonight, it is likely to table a single line bill for a general election tomorrow (which would be very similar the one proposed by the Liberal Democrats and backed by the SNP over the weekend, and would only require a simple majority in parliament), said Downing Street sources. Shortly after, a Liberal Democrat source suggested that they may back the Government’s one-line bill for a general election, but the bill would have to meet three conditions of avoiding no deal Brexit, dropping the WAB and the date must be “set in stone”. Lib Dem sources added they are unlikely to support amendments to the election bill such as votes for 16-year olds or EU nationals. Later reports suggested that the government is willing to meet these conditions, although there is still reportedly “wrangling” over the date of the election. With Tory/ex Tory and Liberal Democrat support, the bill appears to have the numbers to pass. The date proposed by the Liberal Democrats over the weekend would fix an election for December 9th, while the government were pushing for a 12th December election date. Any potential bill, if brought forward by the government, could be moved through Parliament between Tuesday and Thursday. Labour, reportedly resigned to the fact that an election in December seems probable (via a single line bill outlined above), indicated they may abstain tonight at the government’s FTPA motion, which if passed, would set an election for 12th December – it is worth noting that this vote is still unlikely to pass as it needs 2/3s of MPs to vote in favour. Either way, with the probability of an election this year seemingly rising, Labour may be wary of the optics of an opposition party continuing to block an election. In another twist, reports suggested that No10 is in talks with Labour Leavers and ex-Tories about bringing another programme motion for the WAB tomorrow. In terms of timings for tonight; the government’s FTPA motion is to be voted on after 17:00 GMT.

* EU EXTENSION: The EU will give the UK a 3-month Brexit extension (to January 31st) with an option to leave earlier (UK press speculated on either November 30th or December 31st), announced EU Council President Tusk, if the UK can ratify the deal it reached with the EU. The proposal is also said to include a provision which prevents the UK from seeking to renegotiate the Withdrawal Agreement at some point in the future. France has reportedly dropped its opposition to a three-month delay (it had been pushing for a much shorter extension).

content: Via Twitter
analysis_details: • As a reminder; UK PM Johnson will bring a motion to parliament today, asking for an election on December 12th under the Fixed Term Parliament Act - this motion would need 2/3s (434) of MPs to vote in favor. Coming in to the week, the assumption had been that the motion would be unlikely to succeed given the Labour Party’s opposition to an election (the party says it opposes an election until “no deal is taken off of the table” - although strategists note the party facing losing a substantial number of seat at the general election according to current polling). However, this morning, EU Council President Tusk announced that the EU would grant a the UK a three-month extension. There were weekend reports that Labour's "until no deal is off the table" criteria had shifted to no longer include a three-month extension as sufficient - however, wary of the way such a shift may appear to the public, the above news from ITV's Brand may be the first indications that Labour are shifting to supporting (or at least not blocking) an early election, which would most likely be held in early December.

RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 28th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

28th October 2019

  • 48.8% of the S&P 500's market cap has reported Q3 results. Earnings are beating by 4.6%, with 73% of companies exceeding their bottom-line estimates. This compares to 5.4% and 71% over the past 3 years. Q3 expectations are for revenues, earnings, and EPS growth of 1.6%, -2.8%, and -0.8%, respectively. EPS is on pace for +1.0%, assuming a typical beat rate for the remainder of the season.
  • Of note for automakers, UAW union has formally ratified the General Motors (GM) 2019 Collective Bargaining Agreement, ending the longest automotive strike in half a century, which now sees an USD 11,000 per member signing bonus, performance bonuses, two 3% annual raises and two 4% lump sum payments and stable health care costs. The UAW has announced it will be targeting Ford (F) now for contract bargaining, Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) is also in the union’s crosshairs. In the wake of the 46k worker GM strike, the October US payrolls report is expected to see a negative deviation where workers who did not receive a paycheck during the period are considered unemployed.
  • Of note for semiconductors, Digi Times reports China National Integrates Circuit Industry Investment fund is to invest CNY 200bln in 2nd phase of support for local chip makers.
  • Barron's published its fall 2019 Big Money poll this weekend. Only 27% of the survey respondents were bullish on equities for the forward 12 months. That was down from 49% in the spring survey and 59% a year ago. It's the lowest percentage of bulls in 20 years. This scepticism could provide the "wall of worry" that allows equities to continue to move higher.

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has had positive mentions and PT rises at Credit Suisse, Jefferies and JPMorgan, where the latter caveats not to buy ahead of earnings. Jefferies cites strong analysis of foot traffic in retail stores and Credit Suisse sees a strong launch season.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense), as according to the NY Times following interviews with regulators and industry, assisted the craft of legislation that reduced oversight from regulation ahead of the two fatal 737 MAX crashes. N.B. CEO Dennis Muilenburg will testify in congress, beginning Tuesday.
  • Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) is looking to divest its Billings, Montana refinery (60k BPD capacity); Valero (VLO) and Marathon Petroleum (MPC) have reportedly toured the facility. Elsewhere, President Trump has said he is interested in a deal with Exxon, or another energy co, to tap into Syrian oil reserves.
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) and Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) – Microsofthas secured the landmark USD 10bln cloud computing contract from the Pentagon after the DoJ ruling, at a loss to contract competitor Amazon, which was favoured to win the contract. CNet reported that whilst incumbent, Defense Secretary Mattis was ordered by President Trump for Amazon to be “screwed” in the contract, to which he reportedly ruled against. In the wake, Business Insider reports that Amazon’s AWS is still evaluating options and is surprised by the decision.
  • Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) (Consumer Staples/Drug Retail) Q3 19 (USD): Adj EPS 1.43 (exp. 1.41), Revenue 34.0bln (exp. 33.89bln); US retail comp pharmacy sales +5.4%, international comp pharmacy sales -1.0% on constant currency basis. FY EPS view 5.96 (exp. 5.98); raises annual cost savings target from excess of 1.5bln, to excess of 1.8bln.

NASDAQ 100

  • Mylan N.V. (MYL) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) is conducting a voluntary nationwide recall of its Alprazolam Tablets due to potential foreign substance presence.
  • Tesla Inc (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) CEO Elon Musk said that demand is far ahead of supply for its solar roofs. Elsewhere, China Global Times reported that Chinese vehicle part/components manufacturers are vying to be included in Tesla’s supply chain.

S&P 500

  • AT&T Inc. (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) Q3 19 (USD): Adj EPS 0.94 (exp. 0.93), Revenue 44.6bln (exp. 45.0bln); postpaid net subscriber additions -217k, net 3.7mln wireless subscribers. FY adj. EPS view seen between 3.60-3.70 (exp. 3.62); FY20 Revenue growth view at +1 to +2%. Provides three-year capital allocation plan. Announces CEO transition not expected in 2020, with one prospective new director to be considered at the next board meeting and another in 2020. Elsewhere, AT&T is to sell its majority stake in Central European Media Enterprises, or CME, for USD 1.1bln to the Czech investment firm PPF Group.
  • DTE Energy Co. (DTE) (Utilities/Multi-Utilities) Q3 19 (USD): EPS 1.91 (exp. 1.98); raises dividend +7% to 1.0125 per share. Raises FY operating EPS view to 6.06 to 6.40 (exp. 6.25, prev. 6.02-6.38); FY20 operating EPS view 6.47-6.75 (exp. 6.59).
  • Prologis (PLD) (Real Estate/Industrial REITs) will acquire Liberty Property Trust (LPT) (Real Estate/Equity REITs) at an EV of USD 12.6bln in an all-stock transaction.
  • Tiffany & Co. (TIF) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) - LVMH (MC FP) has offered a USD 14.5bln takeover offer for Tiffany, USD 120 share, in a bid to expand its presence in the US jewellery market. FT reported that Tiffany is likely to reject the bid, believing it undervalues the jewellery maker. Tiffany has since announced it will review the offer carefully, however.
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) (Financials/Diversified Banks) has reportedly cut over 200 bankers, mainly those who provide loans to energy firms and farmers.

OTHER

  • HSBC (HSBA LN, HSBC) (Financials/Banks) – Q3 revenue USD 13.3bln vs. Prev. USD 13.8bln, net USD 3.0bln vs. Prev. USD 3.9bln, adj. Pretax USD 5.35bln vs. Exp. USD 5.7bln. Pretax profit USD 4.84bln vs. Exp. USD 5.30bln. CET1 ratio 14.3% vs. Prev. 14.3%. Co. no longer intends to achieve its ROTE target in excess of 11% in 2020. Co. notes ‘significant’ restructuring charges as they deal with a deterioration in the global outlook. CEO Quinn states that in some areas, performance was not acceptable, particularly continental Europe, and previous plans for these areas are not enough; as such, increasing plans to remodel and transition capital into better return/growth areas.
  • ON Semiconductor (ON) (Information Technology/Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) ) Q3 19 (USD): EPS 0.33 (exp. 0.36), Revenue 1.38bln (exp. 1.38bln). Q4 Revenue view 1.35bln-1.4bln (exp. 1.37bln).
  • Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) has begun restoring power to almost 3mln customers across California after a deliberate power cut in anticipation to extreme wind, although the co may have to cut power again with more weather warnings for the next few days, which will also weigh on competitor Edison International (EIX).
  • Restaurant Brands International Inc (QSR) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) Q3 19 (USD): EPS 0.72 (exp. 0.73), Revenue 1.458bln (exp. 1.46bln); Tim Hortons SSS -1.4%, Burger King SSS +4.8%, Popeyes +9.7%. WSJ reported that Popeyes is returning the availability of the much-popular chicken sandwich next month.
  • Spotify Technology SA (SPOT) (Communication Services/Entertainment) Q3 19 (EUR): EPS 0.36 (exp. -0.36), Revenue 1.731bln (exp. 1.73bln); CFO is to retire on January 15th. MAU’s +31% YY at 248mln, outperforming high end of co’s previous guidance.
  • Square Inc (SQ) (Information Technology/IT Services) has been mentioned cautiously in Barron's, citing its 60x forward P/E ratio as too high given it is more of a financial tech/hardware co than a software, and should trade at similar multiples to the likes of PayPal (PYPL), Visa (V) and Mastercard (MA) which trade at ratios around 30 times forward earnings.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 28th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are little changed this morning on a lack of newsflow
  • European Council President Tusk announces that "The EU27 has agreed that it will accept the UK's request for a Brexit "flextension" until 31 January 2020
  • China’s MOFCOM stated the technical consultations of some of the text agreement for the deal with US were basically completed and that the sides agreed to properly handle their core concerns
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB’s Draghi & BoE’s Tenreyro
  • Earnings: Alphabet & T-Mobile
  • Reminder, UK clocks moved back 1hr such that the London-New York time gap is 4 hours for this week

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week with a positive tone after trade hopes were spurred by the recent top-level call between US and China negotiators in which the sides were said to be close to finalising some sections of the phase one deal. This lifted all US majors on Friday and saw the S&P 500 approach to within less than half a point of its record high, fuelled by outperformance in the trade sensitive sectors, although the gains in the Asia-Pac region were mostly moderate amid calm before this week’s storm of risk events. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) marginally benefitted from the trade optimism and as commodity-related stocks kept the Australian index afloat, while the advances in Japan were limited by the recent mixed performance in its currency. Elsewhere, Chinese markets outperform amid encouraging earnings from some of China’s Big 4 banks including ICBC and with Hang Seng (+0.8%) also underpinned by the inclusion of dual class listed stocks in the Stock Connect and amid anticipation of another 25bps rate cut at this week’s FOMC which would force the HKMA to move in lock-step with the Fed. However, the index later retraced some of the gains after weaker results from HSBC and with the Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) somewhat restricted after a PBoC liquidity drain and the steepest contraction to Chinese Industrial Profits since 2015. Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower on spillover selling from recent declines in T-notes and as stocks mildly benefitted from the trade optimism, but with downside stemmed amid BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1.1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for net daily drain of CNY 50bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0762 vs. Exp. 7.0769 (Prev. 7.0749)

China’s MOFCOM stated the technical consultations of some of the text agreement for the deal with US were basically completed and that the sides agreed to properly handle their core concerns. China’s Global Times noted that this is the first time the Chinese side signalled that a partial agreement may be within reach. (Global Times)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Sep) Y/Y -5.3% (Prev. -2.0%). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said Islamic State leader Al-Baghdadi died in a US raid in Syria, while it was also reported that the French Interior Minister instructed police to be on high alert to prevent potential revenge attacks following the death of the IS leader. (Newswires)

US Vice Chief of Naval Operations Burke says North Korean submarine-launched ballistic missiles must not be underestimated and that such weapons could pose a direct threat to the US mainland. (KBS)

UK/EU

European Council President Tusk announces that "The EU27 has agreed that it will accept the UK's request for a Brexit "flextension" until 31 January 2020. The decision is expected to be formalised through a written procedure" (Twitter)

UK’s Liberal Democratic party have drawn up a bill that amends the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, fixing an election for December 9th. If the bill is adopted by the UK PM, it could be taken through Parliament this Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. Further, the SNP party said it will back the bill which would give it the numbers to pass, according to Observer’s Michael Savage. Further, MPs are due to vote later on the Government’s call to have an election on December 12th, which if approved, the Brexit bill would resume its passage through Parliament until it is dissolved on November 6th. (Twitter/BBC)

Following the EU27 flextension acceptance, Liberal Democrats consensus is that they will continue to back an election, though no final decision has been taken as of yet., Telegraph's Rayner. (Twitter)

UK Government believes that the new House of Commons Speaker, as Bercow is to retire at month-end, will be less likely to allow MPs to seize control of the order paper; as such hopes are that the new speaker will assist in attaining a general election. (Times)

German Chancellor Merkel’s Christian Democratic party suffered a setback in an election for state assembly in the eastern state of Thuringi whilst the populist right winged AfD party more than doubled its standing and was marginally ahead of CDU. (Newswires)

Opinion Polls showed the Conservative Party have a 16-point lead at 40% of support vs. 24% of support for Labour. (Sky News) 

EQUITIES

A choppy start to the week for European equities [Eurostoxx 50 Unch] as the region failed to sustain the positivity seen during APAC hours in which Mainland China and Hong Kong outperformed on trade optimism. Major bourses are tentative as is usually the case ahead of a risk-packed week which sees the latest FOMC/BoJ policy meetings, German Prelim CPI, EZ flash CPI, US ISM Manufacturing, US labour market report and a slew large-cap earnings. Sectors are mixed with pressure seen in Financials as heavyweight HSBC (-4.1%) slumped post-earnings after missing on adj. pretax and revenue expectations, whilst stating that it no longer intends to achieve its ROTE target and notes of “significant” restructuring charges amid a deterioration in the global outlook.  On the flip side, consumer discretionary outperform as jewellery makers benefit from LVMH’s (+0.3%) unsolicited bid to acquire Tiffany (+20% pre-market), which is poised to be rejected according to sources cited by the FT. Thus, the likes of Pandora (+1.3%), Richemont (+2.1%) and Swatch (+1.4%) are lifted in tandem. Turning to individual stocks, Bankia (-3.0%) shares fell after the Co. reported this morning. In terms of bank analysis, JPM favour Euro-area stocks and note that international shares are set to outperform those in the US. JPM also maintains a bullish outlook on global equities but also expect rotation into cyclicals and value shares benefitting non-US equities more. Elsewhere, the analysts are overweight on Japan, neutral regarding the US, underweight on the UK and neutral for EM.

Microsoft (MSFT) – Have secured the Pentagon’s USD 10bln cloud computing contract, as such Co. are around 3.0% higher in pre-market trade. Amazon (AMZN) had been considered the favourites to win this contract. (Newswires)

FX

USD - The Dollar is holding the bulk of last week’s late recovery gains, with the DXY firmly above 97.500 within a 97.731-896 range and eyeing a potentially pivotal week including the FOMC policy meeting, coupon settlement day, month end, NFP and the manufacturing ISM. In the interim, preliminary trade data will overshadow wholesale inventories today after reports that the US and China are close to finalising elements of the Phase 1 pact, while Tuesday’s highlights are likely to be consumer confidence and pending home sales.

AUD/EUR/NZD/GBP - Although the Greenback remains underpinned overall, as noted above, the Aussie, Euro, Kiwi and Pound are all marginally firmer, with Aud/Usd maintaining 0.6800+ status, Eur/Usd inching towards 1.1100, Nzd/Usd pivoting 0.6350 and Cable hovering above 1.2800 between 1.2860-10 broad parameters. Note, Asia-Pacific trade was hampered somewhat by the NZ market holiday (Labour Day), but early EU activity boosted by some demand for Sterling that saw the Eur/Gbp cross test 10 DMA support at 0.8629 amidst expectations that the EU will respond favourably to the latest UK Brextension request, which has subsequently been confirmed by EC President Tusk and leaves the Pound prone to another showdown in Westminster as PM Johnson continues to push for a GE. Meanwhile, a decent expiry option may cap Eur/Usd given 1.3 bn rolling off at the 1.1100 strike.

JPY/CAD/CHF - All fractionally softer vs the Buck, as the Yen straddles 108.70 ahead of the BoJ and remains wary about possible policy action or more dovish guidance, while the Loonie is looking at the BoC for more independent direction having strengthened recently to breach 1.3100 and test the next line of resistance at 1.3050 that also coincides with a 1.3051 Fib retracement. Elsewhere, no looming SNB meeting to consider for the Franc, but latest weekly Swiss sight deposits suggest the Bank has been back in action as Usd/Chf hovers around 0.9950 and Eur/Chf climbs towards 1.1050.

EM - Yet more Rand and Lira outperformance, with the former encouraged by Eskom declaring no further load-shedding for Monday or this week at this stage, while the latter continues to welcome a thawing in Turkish-US/international relations over Syria. However, the Argentinian Peso is lamenting the weekend election result revealing a win for Fernandez that has prompted the authorities to implement capital controls.

Argentina President Macri conceded defeat following the election and congratulated President-elect Fernandez, while the Argentina central bank later tightened restrictions on USD purchases with limits for individuals lowered to USD 200 per month from USD 10000 per month and the central bank president will hold a press conference 0830 local time (11:30 GMT) on Monday. (Newswires)

Larger FX option expiries for today's NY cut:

- EUR/USD: 1.1040 (226M), 1.1065 (300M), 1.1085-90 (500M), 1.1100 (1.3BLN)

FIXED INCOME

Gilts have been front-running the more recent recovery in debt futures and bouts of consolidation/short covering, with the 10 year benchmark cutting its arrears to just 10 ticks at 132.26 vs 62 ticks at worst, as markets await the outcome of PM Johnson’s next attempt to win backing for a GE. Meanwhile, Bunds have drifted back below 171.00 and the UST equivalent is holding just above the 129-05 overnight session low ahead of advance trade data, wholesale inventories and Dallas Fed manufacturing that kick-off a blockbuster week in relatively calm fashion.

COMMODITIES                                      

WTI and Brent are softer this morning but not by any significant magnitude thus far on a lack of fundamental newsflow as markets begin another packed week in a tentative fashion. Crude specific newsflow include comments from the Russian Energy Ministry; who noted that it is too early to discuss deeper OPEC+ cuts, which dampens the source reports seen last week. Further, the Ministry noted that OPEC+ will consider the US’ oil output growth slowdown in their December decision, for reference OPEC+ are expected to revise policy when they convene on December 6th. Last Friday’s Baker Hughes print for oil rigs was the lowest reading since April 2017 and therefore the oil rig count has dropped by 189 this year. Elsewhere, UBS note that recent indicators of weakness including this year’s rig decreases and a employment slowdown in Texas indicate that prices above USD 56/bbl for WTI are necessary to justify the maintenance or expansion of current oil production levels. In terms of metals - spot gold is flat and remains within relatively narrow USD 5/oz ranges above the USD 1500/oz mark heading into key risk events this week. Elsewhere, copper prices are on the backfoot amid further deterioration in China’s industrial profits which was the steepest fall in four years.

BREXIT UPDATE: EU to grant 3 month flextension, Johnson's push for election likely to fail
content:
* EU EXTENSION LATEST: The EU will give the UK a 3-month Brexit extension (to January 31st) with an option to leave earlier (UK press speculated on either November 30th or December 31st), announced EU Council President Tusk, if the UK can ratify the deal it reached with the EU. The proposal is also said to include a provision which prevents the UK from seeking to renegotiate the Withdrawal Agreement at some point in the future. France has reportedly dropped its opposition to a three-month delay (it had been pushing for a much shorter extension).

* UK ELECTION LATEST: Across the channel, UK PM Johnson will bring a motion to parliament today, asking for an election on December 12th under the Fixed Term Parliament Act: this motion would need 2/3s (434) of MPs to vote in favour and is unlikely to succeed given the Labour Party’s opposition to an election. The party says it opposes an election until “no deal is taken off of the table”, something which they are now saying a three-month extension does not do, says the party – it is worth noting that the latest polls put Labour in a weak position, at 24% to the Conservatives 40%. Elsewhere, the opposition Liberal Democratic party have drawn up a bill that amends the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, fixing an election for December 9th. The SNP also threw their weight behind the bill, which, according to commentators, which could give it the numbers to pass if the government also backed the bill – both parties could benefit from the fact that university students would still be at their campuses on the 9th. The government, however, has ruled out support for such a motion, calling it a “gimmick” that opposition parties would use to stop Parliament from debating Brexit.

* OTHER ROUTES TO AN ELECTION: The opposition or PM Johnson himself could call for a vote of no confidence, which only requires a simple majority to pass. Thereafter, Party leaders would have 14 days to form a new government that can win a confidence vote; Johnson’s government would be given the first shot it is party with the most seats. If they fail, Labour could also try, and failing that, other parties could try to form a government of national unity.

subject: Noumra Quants: a dip in optimism could present a good opportunity to buy low
content:
• Global stock market sentiment appears to be neutral to slightly positive, and therefore still healthy, adding that the current risk-on environment is yet to venture into euphoria and is some way away from being seen as unsustainable.
  • Markets could see a drop in optimism this week (28th October through November 1st), however, should this take place in a predictable range, there could be an opportunity for a revival in risk around November 5th i.e. presenting investors an opportunity to buy low.
  • CTAs have swung to making trend-following purchases of S&P 500 futures (tentative) and NASDAQ 100 futures (more rapid). The end of last week saw investors return to selling defensives and low beta stocks, whilst purchasing cyclicals and higher beta names. CTAs' net long position in NASDAQ 100 futures have climbed back up to 45% of the peak level (26th September).
  • The VIX is being sold in the futures market, even as it is being bought in the options market. Hedge funds are typically seen as sellers of VIX futures, whilst global macro hedge funds are beginning to see US stocks as overvalued and are paying some credence to the threat from hard-to-predict downside risks.

subject: Bunds: probing below the lower bound of recent ranges
content: A rather tame rebound from overnight lows was snuffed out when the 10 year German benchmark hit parity at 171.35, and bears have subsequently tightened their grip on price action to push the core bond through 171.00 amidst considerably heavier volumes as stops were tripped on a breach of the prior Eurex low (171.03) and psychological level. Market contacts are now flagging the 170.79-73 area for some technical support via a rising chart trendline and low from October 17 vs a 170.77 trough so far. The catalysts, more positive US-China trade reports, elevated Fed rate cut expectations that are keeping the US Treasury and other debt curves on a steeper trajectory alongside prospects that the EU will formerly grant the UK another Brex or flextension.

28th October 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week with a positive tone after trade hopes were spurred by the recent top-level call between US and China negotiators in which the sides were said to be close to finalising some sections of the phase one deal. This lifted all US majors on Friday and saw the S&P 500 approach to within less than half a point of its record high, fuelled by outperformance in the trade sensitive sectors, although the gains in the Asia-Pac region were mostly moderate amid calm before this week’s storm of risk events. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) marginally benefitted from the trade optimism and as commodity-related stocks kept the Australian index afloat, while the advances in Japan were limited by the recent mixed performance in its currency. Elsewhere, Chinese markets outperform amid encouraging earnings from some of China’s Big 4 banks including ICBC and with Hang Seng (+1.1%) also underpinned by the inclusion of dual class listed stocks in the Stock Connect and amid anticipation of another 25bps rate cut at this week’s FOMC which would force the HKMA to move in lock-step with the Fed. However, the index later retraced some of the gains after weaker results from HSBC and with the Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) somewhat restricted after a PBoC liquidity drain and the steepest contraction to Chinese Industrial Profits since 2015

FTSE 100

CET1 ratio 14.3% vs. Prev. 14.3%. Co. no longer intends to achieve its ROTE target in excess of 11% in 2020. Co. notes ‘significant’ restructuring charges as they deal with a deterioration in the global outlook. CEO Quinn states that in some areas performance was not acceptable, particularly continental Europe, and previous plans for these areas are not enough; as such, increasing plans to remodel and transition capital into better return/growth areas. (Newswires) Co. traded in excess of 2.0% lower during Asia-Pac hours.

Banks – Treasury Select Committee has concluded that Banks should be required to pay increased regulatory levies to combat IT failures in the financial services sector; which have been described as ‘unacceptable’ (Times)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 28th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets began the week with a positive tone amid trade hopes after China signalled that a partial agreement may be within reach
  • EU is reportedly preparing to allow a 3-month Brexit extension to January 31st 2020 with an option to leave earlier
  • UK’s Liberal Democratic party have drawn up a bill which would fix an election for December 9th, SNP are said to back the bill
  • In FX, DXY traded relatively stable, GBP/USD was subdued, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses traded uneventful
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ M3 Money Supply, ECB’s Draghi & BoE’s Tenreyro
  • Earnings from AT&T, Alphabet, T-Mobile, Loews
  • Reminder, UK clocks moved back 1hr such that the London-New York time gap is 4 hours

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week with a positive tone after trade hopes were spurred by the recent top-level call between US and China negotiators in which the sides were said to be close to finalising some sections of the phase one deal. This lifted all US majors on Friday and saw the S&P 500 approach to within less than half a point of its record high, fuelled by outperformance in the trade sensitive sectors, although the gains in the Asia-Pac region were mostly moderate amid calm before this week’s storm of risk events. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) marginally benefitted from the trade optimism and as commodity-related stocks kept the Australian index afloat, while the advances in Japan were limited by the recent mixed performance in its currency. Elsewhere, Chinese markets outperform amid encouraging earnings from some of China’s Big 4 banks including ICBC and with Hang Seng (+1.1%) also underpinned by the inclusion of dual class listed stocks in the Stock Connect and amid anticipation of another 25bps rate cut at this week’s FOMC which would force the HKMA to move in lock-step with the Fed. However, the index later retraced some of the gains after weaker results from HSBC and with the Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) somewhat restricted after a PBoC liquidity drain and the steepest contraction to Chinese Industrial Profits since 2015. Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower on spillover selling from recent declines in T-notes and as stocks mildly benefitted from the trade optimism, but with downside stemmed amid BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1.1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for net daily drain of CNY 50bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0762 vs. Exp. 7.0769 (Prev. 7.0749)

US President Trump said China will be buying many more agricultural products and wants to make a deal, while he added that talks are going well and that they are working very closely with the Chinese to get a deal. However, there were also reports that White House Trade Adviser Navarro was said to oppose the current language of the phase one deal because he wants it to be tougher on intellectual property. (Newswires/CNBC)

China’s MOFCOM stated the technical consultations of some of the text agreement for the deal with US were basically completed and that the sides agreed to properly handle their core concerns. China’s Global Times noted that this is the first time the Chinese side signalled that a partial agreement may be within reach. (Global Times)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Sep) Y/Y -5.3% (Prev. -2.0%). (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

EU is preparing to allow a 3-month extension to January 31st 2020 with an option to leave earlier, on November 30th or December 31st, if a deal is ratified but was also said to rule out any potential to renegotiate the Withdrawal Agreement and requires the UK to meet EU obligations during the extension. EU diplomats are to meet at 09:00 GMT (10:00 local time) to discuss the proposal. France has reportedly agreed to 3-month Brexit extension, according to Politico. (Guardian/FT/Politico)

UK’s Liberal Democratic party have drawn up a bill that amends the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, fixing an election for December 9th. If the bill is adopted by the UK PM, it could be taken through Parliament this Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. Further, the SNP party said it will back the bill which would give it the numbers to pass, according to Observer’s Michael Savage. Further, MPs are due to vote later on the Government’s call to have an election on December 12th, which if approved, the Brexit bill would resume its passage through Parliament until it is dissolved on November 6th. (Twitter/BBC)

UK Government believes that the new House of Commons Speaker, as Bercow is to retire at month-end, will be less likely to allow MPs to seize control of the order paper; as such hopes are that the new speaker will assist in attaining a general election. (Times)

German Chancellor Merkel’s Christian Democratic party suffered a setback in an election for state assembly in the eastern state of Thuringi whilst the populist right winged AfD party more than doubled its standing and was marginally ahead of CDU. (Newswires)

Opinium Poll showed Conservative Party with a 16-point lead at 40% of support vs. 24% of support for Labour. (Sky News)

S&P affirmed UK at AA; Outlook Negative, while it upgraded Greece to BB-; Outlook Positive and cited receding budgetary risks and lifting of capital controls. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Netherlands at 'AAA'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires) 

 

FX

FX price action was relatively muted in the region owing to a light calendar, several holiday closures (New Zealand, Singapore & India) and ahead of this week’s slew of risk events which includes the FOMC and culminates with Friday’s NFP jobs data. As such, the DXY traded relatively stable and held on to last week’s spoils as its major counterparts remained lacklustre with EUR/USD stuck near last week’s lows beneath the 1.1100 handle. GBP/USD was also subdued and approached closer towards 1.2800 to the downside ahead of PM Johnson’s attempt to get a snap election passed through Parliament today, while the latest reports concerning Brussels continued to suggest the EU is preparing to grant the UK request for a 3-month Brexit extension with the bloc’s ambassadors to meet early this week to finalize the agreement. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses traded uneventful and antipodeans were also subdued amid a quiet overnight session and holiday-thinned conditions.

Argentina President Macri conceded defeat following the election and congratulated President-elect Fernandez, while the Argentina central bank later tightened restrictions on USD purchases with limits for individuals lowered to USD 200 per month from USD 10000 per month and the central bank president will hold a press conference 0830 local time (11:30 GMT) on Monday. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities conformed to the relatively quiet tone seen across asset classes ahead of this week’s key announcements and with several market closures overnight, which provided an opportunity for some mild profit taking of last week’s gains in oil and resulted to a pullback in WTI crude futures to the USD 56.50/bbl level. Elsewhere, gold flatlined and held above the USD 1500/oz amid a steady greenback and with participants side-lined by an anticipated Fed rate cut as well as US NFP jobs data later this week, while copper mirrored the uneventful trade across the complex but was kept afloat amid the mild positive risk tone from the heightened US-China trade hopes.

Baker Hughes Rig Count: Oil rigs -17 at 696, gas rigs -4 at 133, total rigs -21 at 830. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said Islamic State leader Al-Baghdadi died in a US raid in Syria, while it was also reported that the French Interior Minister instructed police to be on high alert to prevent potential revenge attacks following the death of the IS leader. (Newswires)

US Vice Chief of Naval Operations Burke says North Korean submarine-launched ballistic missiles must not be underestimated and that such weapons could pose a direct threat to the US mainland. (KBS)

US At settlement, the curve had bear-flattened, shaking off an early risk-off feeling; downside today was sponsored by constructive chatter after a phone call between US/China negotiators, which even trade hawk Navarro described as ‘excellent’. The complex did find a modest bid in quiet afternoon trade, as equities faded from near-record highs, perhaps also aided later by news that trade advisor Navarro was pushing for tougher language on IP protections. Next week, the complex will take more cues from the fundamental side of the equation, with FOMC, NFP and ISMs on tap; currently, markets are pricing with near certainty a 25bps rate cut to 1.50-1.75%; key will be how the Fed guides after it has completed its ‘insurance cuts’; currently, money markets imply easing of a 29bps into year-end (just over one cut priced), and 57bps of cuts is priced through end-2020 (implying just over 2 rate cuts by the end of next year, include the potential cut on Wednesday). US T-note futures (Z9) settled 10 ticks lower at 129-17.

This lifted all US majors on Friday and saw the S&P 500 approach to within less than half a point of its record high, fuelled by outperformance in the trade sensitive sectors, although the gains in the Asia-Pac region are mostly moderate amid calm before this week’s storm of risk events. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) marginally benefit from the trade optimism with commodity-related stocks keeping the Australian index afloat, while the advances in Japan have been limited by the recent mixed performance in its currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.3%) outperforms as markets anticipate another 25bps rate cut at this week’s FOMC which would force the HKMA to move in lock-step with the Fed, while gains in the Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) are to a lesser extent after PBoC liquidity inaction and the steepest contraction to Chinese Industrial Profits since 2015.

FX price action has been relatively muted in the region owing to a light calendar, several holiday closures (New Zealand, Singapore & India) and ahead of this week’s slew of risk events including the FOMC and which culminates with Friday’s NFP jobs data. As such, the DXY is relatively stable and marginally extends on last week’s strength as its major counterparts remain lacklustre with EUR/USD stuck near last week’s lows beneath the 1.1100 handle. GBP/USD is also subdued and approaches 1.2800 to the downside ahead of PM Johnson’s attempt to get a snap election passed through Parliament today, while the latest reports concerning Brussels continue to suggest the EU is preparing to grant the UK request for a 3-month Brexit extension with the bloc’s ambassadors to meet early this week to finalize the agreement. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses trade uneventful and antipodeans are also unchanged amid a quiet overnight session and holiday-thinned conditions.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower as they track the recent declines in T-notes and as stocks mildly benefit from the trade optimism, but with downside stemmed amid BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1.1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.
